seg.output:
Greetings and peace from the Lord, etc. I cannot thank you enough for all the kindness you have shown me. I hope that one day I will be able to repay you in some way, even if not in full – but, for now, you can still consider me to be highly recommended by you. There are many things I would have liked to talk about with you, if I had not been afraid that the letters would be intercepted. Recently I had also written to you, but the messenger left the letters behind in Mellingen. I am glad that there is nothing written in those letters that I should fear, since I am certain that the host in Mellingen, Faßbinder, does not wish me or you any harm. Soon it will be possible for either you to come here when you travel to Bern or for me to go to Tygur, and then we will be able to discuss everything to our satisfaction.
Farewell, and please tell my friend and brother John Sebastian Bestly that our magistrate is sending him this letter, so that he can come to us as soon as possible. Please give my greetings to your wife and children, M. Leon, Utynger and his wife, Mr. Heinrich Goldly, Mr. Vyß and whoever else has asked about me. And I have not forgotten that I am still in your debt for the shoes for my wife.
Given on the 12th of June, 1532.
Yours always,
John Zender
To the most honourable and learned Mr. Heinrich Bullinger, a priest at Tygur, my most esteemed friend and brother.

seg.output: I cannot adequately express my gratitude to you for all the kindnesses you have shown me. I hope that something will soon turn up which will enable me to make some return, however inadequate; meanwhile, please remember me as much as ever. I should have a great deal to say to you, with which I could not now amuse you orally, but for my fear of the letters being intercepted. I wrote to you not long ago, but the messenger left the letters at Mellen. I have no fear of anything being written in them that I need to fear, as I can trust the host at Mellen, Fasbinder, to bear me no ill will. Before long, either I shall come to you when you go to Berne, or you to me at Zurich, when we shall discuss everything to our heart's content. Farewell, and remember my choice of John Sebastian Bestly for our chaplain. The magistrate is sending him these letters, that he may come to us as soon as he can. Salutations to your wife and children, M. Leon, Utynger and his wife, Heinrich Goldly, Vyss, and all who have asked after me. I have not forgotten that I owe you a pair of hose for your wife. Written on the twelfth of June, 1532. Yours always, John Zender. To M. Heinrich Bullinger, a most worthy and learned man, priest at Zurich, my most esteemed friend and brother.
